page.title: 11ECOLOGY OF GLENLIVET
page.content: A variation of over 700m from the tree-edged banks of the clear-running Avon to the Cromdales makes the wild life vary too. Meadow birds, flowers and butterflies are seen on the lower and cultivated ground. Native birch, rowan and alder give the birds cover. By the river, renowned for its salmon fishing, mimulus grows amongst the rounded stones. Dippers bob between flights over the water and otters roam the banks but are seldom seen. Higher up is uncultivated except for conifers, home of the red squirrel. Orchids and bog-myrtle abound; Argus butterflies flit among the grass; Bees hum while grouse, golden plover and curlews cry over the heather which hides the cranberries. A lovely area with an active Conservation group to guard its amenities.
